Chapter 6, part 9 on distinguishing sages, relying on the stage of non-returners, various approaches are established in the sÅ«tras, now the characteristics of their distinctions should be discussed.
Verse:
Here, there are those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a through birth, through practice,
and through no practice. Those who go upstream, if they cultivate a mixture, can go to the ultimate form realm,
half-leaping, fully submerging, the rest can go to the peak of existence,
those who go to the formless realms are of four types, attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a while dwelling here.
Discussion:
In general, there are seven types of non-returners. Those who proceed to the form realm are of five types:

1. those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state, 2. those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a upon birth, 3. those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a through practice, 4. those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a without practice, 5. those who go upstream.
Because they attain nirvana in the middle, they are called those who attain nirvana in the middle.

In this way, it should be understood that because they attain nirvana after birth, through practice, and without practice, they are called those who attain nirvana after birth, etc. Because they go to a higher realm, they are called those who go to a higher realm.
As for those who attain nirvana in the middle, there is a type of person who has attained the cessation of discernment of the bonds of birth, but not so for the bonds of arising.

When they encounter conditions that afflict the desire realm, they are able to encourage themselves to cultivate the superior practice of severing the remaining bonds. Before the practice is complete, they encounter conditions that cause them to lose their life and thus end their life. By the power of the bonds of arising, they receive a form intermediate existence. Because they are disgusted with much suffering, they advance the path that arose previously to sever the remaining bonds, accomplish arhatship, and attain parinirvÄá¹‡a.

As for those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a through birth, there is a type of person who, due to having previously completed karma that accords with birth and has increased it, falls from the desire realm and receives birth in the form realm. Due to possessing the practice of the path of swift progress, after being born for not a long time they become arhats and then attain parinirvÄá¹‡a by exhausting their life span.

Based on the remaining support, it is said that they attain parinirvÄá¹‡a through birth. It is not that as soon as they are born they attain parinirvÄá¹‡a without remainder, because they lack mastery in the middle of abandoning life.

As for those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a through practice and those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a without practice, there is a type of person who, after being born for a long time, then becomes a post-learner. Among them, there is one who is vigorous in effort and one who is by nature slow and lazy. They are respectively called those who practice and those who do not practice.

That is, if one first in the realm of desire, by the power of samÄdhi that does not rest in the practice of added effort, severs the five lower bonds and becomes an anÄgÄmin, and later, born in the realm of form, after many days, he is still able to cultivate the path of the same kind and become an arhat, he is called one who attains nirvÄá¹‡a through practice.
One who attains nirvÄá¹‡a without practice is the opposite of this.

Or, after being born in the realm of form for many days, he relies on the practice of suffering and is liberated from the remaining bonds, and is called one who attains nirvÄá¹‡a through practice, because he cultivates and attains nirvÄá¹‡a by means of the path that relies on effort.
The opposite of this is called one who attains nirvÄá¹‡a without practice.

Isnâ€™t it the case that the practices relied on by those who attain nirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state, those who attain nirvÄá¹‡a after birth, and those who attain nirvÄá¹‡a through manifestation also have these two kinds? Therefore, the names of those who attain nirvÄá¹‡a through practice and those who attain nirvÄá¹‡a without practice should be established?
There is no such error, because although the meaning is the same, they each have different stages.

That is, although those who attain nirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state, etc., also definitely rely on the practice of suffering and the practice of pleasure to be liberated from the remaining bonds, they each have different stages, and in contrast to this, they are called different in the sense of not being common;
Because the formless realm does not have such a distinction of stages, the difference is shown by the difference in paths. How can this be used as an example to make them the same?
Therefore, there is no error in the explanation here.

Because of this, some say that the two are distinguished because they attain nirvana in sequence by relying on the conditioned and unconditioned noble paths. One should know that there is also no other error that is the same as this.

The difficulty raised by the master of the treatise has a great error. Although this meaning is well explained, because each has a different stage, there is a sutra that says there is no practice first, and there is also a sutra that first speaks of having practice. Since the time is no different, following the explanation there is no contradiction. Because having practice can be respected, I first explain it.
As for the one who goes upstream, it refers to a type of person whose practice of going upstream increases, and who does not realize complete nirvana in the first place of birth.

It means that after passing away from the desire realm and being reborn in the form realm, one is not yet able to realize complete nirvana in that realm, but only after being reborn in a higher realm can one attain parinirvÄá¹‡a.
This upper stream is divided into two, because of differences in cause and effect.
The difference in cause is that it is due to the presence or absence of mixed cultivation of the trance states.
The difference in effect is that the highest heaven of the form realm and the peak of existence are the ultimate destinations.

That is, if one has mixed cultivation of the trance states, one can go to the highest heaven of the form realm and attain nirvana there, because mixed cultivation can bring about the result of rebirth in the Pure Abodes.

This is further divided into three kinds, because of the differences of complete transcendence, partial transcendence, and complete submergence.ğŸ”½As for complete transcendence, it means that in the form realm one passes away from one place and goes to the highest heaven of the form realm. This is because in a previous existence in the desire realm one had already cultivated the four kinds of trance states, but due to encountering conditions one lost the upper three trance states. Taking the craving for the first trance state as a condition, one's life ends and one is reborn in the Brahma assembly heaven.

Due to the power of being thoroughly familiar with the previous world, one is again able to cultivate the fourth trance state, and passes away from that place and is reborn in the highest heaven of the form realm.

The meaning of complete transcendence is that one first dies in the first of the sixteen heavens of the form realm and is finally reborn in the last of the sixteen heavens, suddenly transcending the intermediate heavens.

The meaning of partial transcendence is that one dies in the first of the sixteen heavens of the form realm and is reborn in the intermediate heavens, and then one is able to transcend one heaven and go to the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha Heaven. This is partial transcendence.

The meaning of complete death is that because one has much craving for the pleasures of the form realm, one is reborn in all the heavens. Because one has craving for the lower heavens in each of the sixteen heavens of the four meditations, this becomes the condition for rebirth. One dies in each of the heavens, from the BrahmakÄyika Heaven, and only then attains parinirvÄá¹‡a in the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha Heaven. Therefore it is called complete death.
By this meaning, it is inferred that the place where MahÄbrahmÄ resides in the first meditation is not a separate place, but is included in the second heaven of Brahmapurohita.
If this were not so, then the abode of the great Brahma would be a place of false views, and there would be no saints who would be reborn there as leaders.
If this were not so, then there would be no difference between the two kinds of nonreturners who die in the lower stages and are reborn in the upper stages.

You should know that of the two kinds of upper stream winners, those who have mixed the four meditations and are reborn in the heaven of the most in the course of evolution and enter nirvana there are called those who go to the peak of existence. Those who do not mix the meditations and are reborn in the heaven of the most in the course of evolution and enter nirvana there are called those who go to the highest.

That is, they do not mix the meditations in advance, and because of craving for the various samÄdhis, they die in the lower stages and are reborn in all the heavens of the realm of form, but they are unable to go to the five pure heavens.

When they die in the realm of form, they are reborn in the three heavens of the formless realm in order, and finally they are reborn in the heaven of the ultimate material form and enter nirvana there.
Of the two kinds of upper stream winners, the former are contemplatives and the latter are practitioners of tranquillization, because they delight in wisdom and delight in samÄdhi, respectively.

It is also reasonable to say that nonreturners who proceed to the upper levels attain nirvana in the lower levels. However, the text says that they go to the highest heaven of the form realm and the highest heaven of the formless realm, because these are the highest places.

Nonreturners do not take a second rebirth in the place where they were born, because they seek a superior rebirth, not one that is equal or inferior. They only die in the realm of desire and are reborn in the form realm.

There are those who attain nirvana in the intermediate state, but not those who die in the form realm and are reborn in the form realm, because there is no disaster in the form realm.ğŸ”½If there are remaining obstacles in the prior existence that prevent nirvana, the same is true of the intermediate state. The intermediate state is inferior to the prior existence, and therefore, if there are obstacles in the prior existence, there must also be obstacles in the intermediate state.

Moreover, if there is an intermediate state, it must belong to the class of nonreturners who proceed to the upper levels, and there would be no difference between those who attain nirvana in the intermediate state and those who proceed to the upper levels.
That is to say, there is no reason to make the distinction that
only those who die in the realm of desire and are reborn in the form realm in the intermediate state attain nirvana.

Those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state are not reborn in the form realm. Why is it that those still learning who have not yet eliminated desire are not reborn in the intermediate state and attain parinirvÄá¹‡a?
Because the body of the intermediate state in the desire realm is weak and lacks the ability to perform many activities.

While in the original state of existence, it is difficult to transcend the dharmas of the desire realm, much less be able to transcend the desire realm and attain the fruit of arhatship in the intermediate state.
Many activities refer to transcending the three realms, permanently eliminating the two kinds of afflictions, and attaining the second and third fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a;
while in the intermediate state, one lacks this ability.
Moreover, one has not yet repeatedly cultivated the antidotes to the nine grades of afflictions before this existence.

Also, the fruits such as non-returner are not attained in the body of the intermediate state, because they are attained through eliminating the dominant afflictions, and it is extremely difficult to be free from the defilements of the three realms. There is no desire in the intermediate state that can attain parinirvÄá¹‡a.
The intermediate state in the form realm is different from this, so there are those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state.
Also, those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in this stage only give rise to the noble path existing in this stage.

Those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state of the first dhyÄna stage only give rise to the noble path of the fundamental dhyÄna of their own stage, not the preliminary or intermediate stages, because it is difficult to manifest them.
In the intermediate state, the body is extremely weak, and only what is easy to give rise to can be manifested.
These five are called those who proceed to the form realm.

Those who proceed to the formless realm are of four types, namely those who, in the desire realm, are free from craving for the form realm and, upon the end of this life, are born in the formless realm. The differences here are only of four kinds, due to the differences in the types such as those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a upon rebirth.
These, together with the previous five, make six non-returners.
There are also those who do not proceed to the form or formless realms, but who, dwelling right here, are able to attain parinirvÄá¹‡a, called those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a upon manifesting.
Together with the previous six, they make seven.

Or, in general, nonreturners should be established as nine types: those who attain nirvana in the present life are divided into two types, one who is able to skillfully discern the holy purport in a previous stage and one who is able to skillfully discern it only at the time of death.
Within those who proceed to the highest, there are also two types, one who proceeds to the form realm and one who proceeds to the formless realm.
Together with the previous four, they become eight, and adding the transformation birth makes nine.
As for transformation birth, it refers to those who have already attained the fruit of stream-entry or once-returner in a previous life, and in this life they attain nonreturner.
The previous term attaining nirvana in the present life only refers to those who attain entry into the noble path and nirvana in the present life.
Or, nonreturners are divided into nine types according to the differences in their faculties, according to their respective abilities.
Or, among the five nonreturners who proceed to the form realm, there are also different categories that are divided into nine types.
A verse says:
There are nine who proceed to the form realm, each divided into three,
Due to differences in karma, afflictions, and faculties, they become three groups of nine.
The treatise says:
The five types of nonreturners who proceed to the form realm are generally divided into three types, each further divided into three types, resulting in nine types.
What are the three?
Because there are distinctions of middle, birth, and upper stream.
How are the three each divided into three?
The middle parinirvÄá¹‡a is divided into three because there are distinctions in attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a upon first arising, reaching a distant place, or a nearby place.
The birth parinirvÄá¹‡a is divided into three because there are distinctions of having practice, lacking practice, or both upon birth.
All of these attain parinirvÄá¹‡a upon birth, and therefore they should all be called birth parinirvÄá¹‡a.
In the upper stream, it is divided into three because there are distinctions of complete transcendence, partial transcendence, and complete submergence.
However, all three types are divided into nine types without confusion because they attain parinirvÄá¹‡a quickly, not quickly, or after a long time.

These three kinds of nonreturners and the nine kinds of nonreturners are distinguished by differences in karma, affliction, and faculties, and thus there are differences in speed, non-speed, and long duration.

They are generally divided into three, because there are differences in karma that accords with the present life, produces rebirth, and produces subsequent lives, which are inferior, middling, and superior, respectively. There are differences in the actual practice of afflictions, and there are differences in superior, middling, and inferior faculties.
Each of these three, as appropriate, also has differences in karma, afflictions, and faculties, and each has three distinctions, thus making nine kinds.
The first two and the third are distinguished by afflictions and faculties, and each has three kinds, not by differences in karma.
The last three are also distinguished by differences in karma that accords with the subsequent life, and thus they are divided into three kinds.
Therefore it is said that nonreturners who proceed to the form realm have distinctions of karma, afflictions, and faculties, and thus become three kinds of nine distinctions.
If this is so, why did the Buddha only speak of seven good destinies in the sutras?
Verse:
The seven destinies of good persons are established, because there is no distinction in the upper stream.
Because of good and evil conduct, non-conduct, going, and no return.
The treatise says:
The middle and the born each have three, and the upper stream is one. The sutra establishes the seven destinies of good persons based on this.
Why are the first two each divided into three, and the third upper stream only established as one?
Because of superior practice, it is called the upper stream. For this reason, it is the same in meaning and is only established as one.
Although the first two are also the same in meaning, the specific characteristics within them are difficult to understand. In order to make them easy to understand, they are each divided into three;
The upper stream has three different characteristics that are easy to understand, so there is no need to further establish distinctions within it.
Moreover, the distinctions of the first two are only so much, and are easy to demonstrate, so they are each divided into three;
The distinctions of the third upper stream are of many kinds, and are difficult to demonstrate, so they are generally established as one.
That is to say, the first and middle parinirvÄá¹‡as are only in the state of being about to be born, and are divided into three kinds due to the differences in faculties and afflictions.
The second, the parinirvÄá¹‡a-at-birth class, is only in the already-born state, and is divided into three kinds because of differences in faculties and passions.

The upper stream has the two kinds of about-to-be-born and already-born. The about-to-be-born upper stream is also of two kinds, namely, those who cultivate meditation with and without admixture. The already-born upper stream is divided into two in the same way.
Moreover, among these two upper streams, if one does not cultivate with admixture, one may be born in the two realms. If one cultivates with admixture, one is born only in one realm.
Those born in one realm are further divided into three, because of the differences of complete transcendence, half transcendence, and complete submergence.

There are many differences within half transcendence. The distinctions of the upper stream are numerous and their characteristics are extensive. If each is individually discussed, it is difficult to fully understand them. Therefore, based on the meaning of equality, the upper stream is generally established.
The middle and born states have few distinctions in meaning and are easily understood, so they are divided into six.
Although each of them also has the meaning of equality, they are equal to the third.
Although there are differences in the upper stream, they are equal to the first two.
The other two are mentioned by implication.

Only these seven have eliminated the desire and hatred, etc., that are not the dharmas of a good person, and they are the closest to the great fruit of a good person, which is the state of post-learner. Therefore the scripture only says that these are the good persons.
This does not mean that the stream-enterer and once-returner cannot be called good persons, because the Buddha also calls them good persons.
As a scripture says:
What is a good person?
It means one who has attained the right view of the learner, up to one who has attained the right concentration of the learner.
Going upward is called progress, which means progress to a higher fruit and progress to a higher rebirth. Therefore only seven are mentioned.
Or only these seven are able to practice good and not practice evil, while the others are not.
Also, only these seven are reborn in the upper realms and do not return again, while the others are not.
Therefore only these are established as the good persons.
Do those who have already been reborn in the holy stages also have these distinctions?ğŸ”½No.
How is it?
A verse says:
The noble ones who have passed through birth in the desire realm will not be reborn in other realms.
Here and in higher realms, there is no cultivation of faculties or falling away.
The treatise says:

The noble ones who have passed through birth in the desire realm will definitely not be reborn in the form or formless realms, because they have already realized the fruit of non-returning and will definitely attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in this very life.

The noble ones who have passed through birth in the form realm may have the meaning of being reborn in the formless realm. However, Sakra DevÄnÄm-Indra said, I have heard of a heaven called Akaniá¹£á¹­ha. After I fall, I will be reborn there. This is because he did not understand the characteristics of the Abhidharma.
After means the final limit of the sovereign karmic ripening of the Thirty-three Heavens.
Falling means that later, if one does not attain the fruit of arhatship.
Will be reborn there means wishing to be reborn in the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha Heaven, not being reborn in the desire realm.
Because Åšakra, having experienced the five signs of death, was extremely distressed and came to the World-Honored One;
as soon as the signs of death disappeared, he said this to bring joy.
Also, observing that it would not benefit him much, the Buddha did not stop him.
Those who have already taken birth in the desire realm and those who have already been born in higher realms are definitely without the cultivation of faculties and regression.
What is the reason for not allowing those who have taken birth in the desire realm and those who have been born in higher realms to have the cultivation of faculties and regression?

Because having already taken birth, the aggregates of one's own continuity accumulate the holy path extremely firmly, and because one attains a superior physical basis, therefore they have no reason for the cultivation of faculties and regression.

It was previously said that the upper stream, by the cause of the mixed cultivation of the dhyÄnas, is able to go to the heaven of the ultimate end of form. First, one should mix and cultivate what kind of dhyÄna?
By what kind of stage does one know that the mixed cultivation is accomplished?
Also, for what reason does one mix and cultivate the dhyÄnas?
The verse says:
First, one mixes and cultivates the fourth, accomplishing it by the mixture of one thought,
In order to experience rebirth and present happiness, and to prevent the retrogression of afflictions.
The treatise says:

Those who wish to mix and cultivate the four meditations must first mix and cultivate the fourth meditation, because that samÄdhi is the most capable, and among the various practices of happiness, it is the most supreme.

That is to say, that meditation has the greatest capability. When it appears in the present, it causes the power of the basis and essence to increase and expand greatly. Therefore, if one relies on that to mix and cultivate meditation, even if one later retrogresses and is reborn in other heavens, due to the power of having previously mixed and cultivated that, one is still able to rely on that to mix and cultivate meditation.
It is precisely by this principle that among the various practices of happiness in the fourth meditation, it is the most supreme, because that comfort and happiness is extremely sublime.
Who is able to mix and cultivate meditation?
Only the noble ones, both learners and post-learners.
In the learner's stage, it is only the faith-liberated and view-attainer. In the post-learner's stage, it is both the timely and untimely.
One must first cultivate the various meditations in the three continents, and one who has fallen back and is reborn in the realm of form is also able to cultivate the various meditations.

How can it be said that the various meditations are common to those who have attained the results of the stages of the path of insight and to those who have attained the results of the stages of the path of cultivation?

That is, one must first cultivate the various meditations in the human realm, and then, having fallen back from the three meditations, one is reborn in the Brahma group of gods. There, one must again be free from the passions of the three meditations in order to be able to again cultivate the various meditations. Having fallen from there, one is then reborn in the Pure Abodes and is then called one who goes upstream.

As was said earlier, those who have attained the results of the stages of the path of insight cannot have this principle, because they do not fall back from the passions that have been eliminated. There is no such error, because it is not admitted that they abide in the faculty of having attained the results of the stages of the path of insight from the beginning.

That is, they first abide in the spiritual family of faith and understanding, cultivate the various meditations, and then fall back and lose them. They then cultivate the refinement of the faculties and perfect the spiritual family of having attained the results of the stages of the path of insight, fearing that they will fall back again later.

When one falls from the realm of desire and is born in the realm of form, one is able to cultivate the trance states in a mixed way, and therefore all six kinds of superior-in-wisdom beings are born in the summit of being.
What expedient methods do they employ in this mixed cultivation?

They must first enter the fourth trance state, and many moments of the pure path appear in succession. From this, they induce many moments of the impure path, and then many moments of the pure path appear again. In this way, they continue to reduce the moments of the pure path one by one until finally two moments of the pure path appear, and then they induce two moments of the impure path. Immediately after this, two moments of the pure path appear again. This is called the completion of the preparatory path of the mixed cultivation of the trance states.

From this point on, by the power of previous effort, they spontaneously induce one moment of the impure path after one moment of the pure path, and immediately after this, one moment of the pure path appears again.

The moment of the impure path in the middle is mixed with the pure path of the preceding and following moments and is therefore called the fundamental, perfected mixed cultivation of the trance states.
Having thus cultivated the fourth meditation with its various aspects, one then, by the power of this, is able to cultivate the first three meditations with their various aspects in the same way.
The essence of the various cultivations of the meditations is the five aggregates.
However, in this matter, all worldly knowledge is cultivated with the four knowledges of dharmas, four of species, and eight knowledges.
Other masters say
that all worldly knowledge is cultivated only with the knowledge of the species of suffering and its cause, because these two can take this as an object.

If this is so, then it is impossible for many pure knowledges to appear and be mixed, and therefore it cannot be said that this is mixed with those. Consequently, the various cultivations of the meditations would not be fully accomplished. This is because it does not arise immediately after the knowledge of dharmas of suffering and its cause, the knowledge of the species of cessation and path, nor do these knowledges arise immediately after it.

There are three reasons for the various cultivations of the meditations: one is for the sake of rebirth; the second is for the sake of present happiness; the third is for the sake of preventing the falling off of the arising of the passions.

That is, if one who has attained the fruit of nonreturner has attained the state of insight and has cultivated the samÄdhi of the four immaterial states, he cultivates the samÄdhi of the four immaterial states for two reasons: one is to receive rebirth, and the second is to experience present happiness.
If it is for the purpose of receiving rebirth, he seeks a superior rebirth, because he is disgusted with a rebirth common to many and delights in a rebirth not common to many.

If it is for the purpose of experiencing present happiness, he delights in the happiness of superior samÄdhi, because worldly samÄdhi is most able to benefit the body, and on this basis one is able to experience present happiness. The impure samÄdhi of the prior and subsequent moments is its assisting companion.

If one of faith and understanding cultivates samÄdhi for these two reasons, he also prevents the arising of passions and the falling away of the fruit. That is, one of dull faculties generates two kinds of pure samÄdhi and, by means of expedient means, protects and guards pure samÄdhi and prevents the samÄdhi of enjoyment from becoming the similar and immediately antecedent condition for defiled samÄdhi.
Therefore among arhats, those of unfixed liberation only cultivate samÄdhi in order to experience present happiness.
Those of fixed liberation seek present happiness and also prevent the arising of passions and the falling away of the fruit.
If one cultivates the samÄdhi of the formless realm in order to be born in the five pure abodes, why are there only five pure abodes?
The verse says:
By the five grades of mixed cultivation, one is born in the five pure abodes.
The treatise says:
Because there are five grades of mixed cultivation of the fourth dhyÄna, the pure abodes are only five.
What are the five grades?
They are distinguished as lower, middle, upper, superior, and supreme grades.
Among them, the first grade is completed by the manifestation of three minds, namely the first pure, next defiled, and then pure.
The second middle grade is completed only after the manifestation of six minds, namely two defiled and four pure mixed cultivations.
In this way, the remaining [grades] are completed only after the manifestation of nine, twelve, and fifteen minds in order.
These five grades of mixed cultivation as causes accordingly produce the fruits of the five pure abodes.
These fifteen minds, defiled and pure, are all those that were not previously acquired but are now acquired.
Other masters say:

The first five pure minds are those that were not previously acquired but are now acquired. The remaining ten minds are those that were previously acquired, because when the first five are present, the future is cultivated. There are those who do not arise from samÄdhi and cultivate the mixed meditation to completion, and there are those who must repeatedly arise from samÄdhi and cultivate the mixed meditation to completion.
Other masters say:

The five pure abodes are attracted by the five faculties of faith, etc., in the order of their predominance, in the sense that sometimes the faculty of faith is predominant in the mixed cultivation of the trance states, and sometimes the faculty of discernment is predominant in the mixed cultivation of the trance states. According to these differences, the five pure abodes are attracted.
Are those who attract the pure abodes attracted by the power of karma or by the power of mixed cultivation?
If it is by the power of karma, then the mixed cultivation of the trance states is useless.
If it is by the power of mixed cultivation, then it contradicts the Piá¹‡á¸a-viniÅ›caya-samuccaya-Å›Ästra.
As that treatise says:
The various places of the Pure Abodes that are born by the power of karma and by the power of mixed cultivation of the dhyanas are called the dharmas of non-ordinary beings.
Some say:
The power of karma produces the Pure Abodes, but the mixed cultivation of the dhyanas is not in vain, because the thought of practicing them is manifested.
Other masters say:
It is the power of mixed cultivation, but it does not contradict the text of the Abhidharmakosa.
That treatise first explains the one who cultivates mixed concentration, in order to show that he enters that concentration first.
Next, it again explains that he is born in the Pure Abodes by the power of karma, in order to show that later, by the power of that [mixed cultivation], he is born in the Pure Abodes.
Here, it is certain that both powers are necessary, because if either is lacking, one is not born there.
However, only contaminated karma produces that retribution, not the power of the uncontaminated, because it abandons existence.
The sutra says that the non-returner is called one who attains by the body. Based on what superior virtue is the one who attains by the body established?
Verse:
Those who attain the concentration of cessation and are non-returners are called those who attain through the body.
The treatise says:

Those who attain the concentration of cessation are called those who attain the concentration of cessation. If non-returners have the attainment of the concentration of cessation in their bodies, they are called those who attain through the body.
This means that non-returners attain a state similar to nirvÄá¹‡a through the body, and are therefore called those who attain through the body.
How can they be called those who attain through the body?

Because they are without mind, because it arises in dependence on the body, and because the attainment arises together with the body and has power, even when it has already ceased, it is still called attainment.
On this point, the author of the treatise says:

The non-returner who advances to eliminate the afflictions to be eliminated by cultivation in the form realm and formless realm, from eliminating one category in the first concentration as the beginning, up to eliminating the eighth category in the peak of existence as the end, should be known as turning to be called a candidate for arhatship.

In this explanation of the candidates for arhatship, the ninth uninterrupted path that eliminates the afflictions of the peak of existence is also called the concentration that is like a vajra. This concentration is firm and sharp, like a vajra, because there is not a single latent tendency that it cannot destroy.
Because it has already destroyed them before, it does not destroy all of them. In reality, it has the ability to destroy all of them.

Since it can destroy the most subtle class of passions, we know that among all the paths of noninterruption, only this moment is called the highest class, and therefore it can eternally eliminate all propensities.

Even though the pure antidote of the path of insight can eliminate the passions of the peak of existence, still, the passions of the peak of existence are divided into nine classes, which can be eliminated in one moment. This shows that the power of these passions is weak.
Since the path of insight is the antidote to weak passions, we know that it cannot destroy all propensities.
If it has the ability to destroy, what prevents it from destroying all?
Therefore it cannot be called diamondlike concentration.

Also, among the propensities, those that are not associated with specific objects are easy to eliminate, and the path of insight is not the highest antidote to them. For this reason, it is not called diamondlike concentration.

The diamondlike concentration explained here is able to eliminate the last and smallest class of propensities that are difficult to eliminate among all those that are associated with specific objects. Therefore it is known that it can destroy all propensities.
By the power of this concentration, one realizes in one moment the acquisition of disjunction from all passions that is not tending toward the fluxes.
The diamond-like concentration is associated with one of six knowledges,
